messageBody:
I don't think that would be wise. That would then couple the framework
to your business object. You would pass your object into the test
suite, which would somehow need to pass it off to your test case. Your
test case would have to know about at the highest level in order for
all test cases to be able to use this construct. It isn't a tight
coupling, but a coupling all the same.

=jason

P.S. I will write the TestSuiteBuilder tonight or this weekend at
submit it to the files list. I will say that I don't really like the
approach though, it was just an option. It opens up room for a lot of
error in what seems to be one of the weakest areas for Java programmers
(at least in the beginning) - the classpath. What if your tests aren't
all so neatly bundled in the same area? Another issue is what if you
have UnitTests* and QuickFunctionalTests** and FunctionalTests*** all
in the same heirarchy of tests? You wouldn't want to have the
TestSuiteBuilder to include all of them. I will think about a way to
deal with this. If I can come up with a clean way (without changing
the framework) I will add this in, if not, well...

=jason

time = (setUp time + test time + tearDown time)

* UnitTest - testing at the method level, generally a very quick
test (time < 2 seconds)
** QuickFunctionalTest - testing functionality (FunctionalTest time <
time > UnitTest time)
*** FunctionalTest - testing functionality (time > 1.5 minutes)

These numbers are based on what I have done in the past on several
teams. They are not standards by any stretch of the imagination, just
guidelines I have used. I found that if my overall UnitTest suite took
more than 2 minutes (which I still consider to be long), I was prone to
run it a lot less. I still would require running UnitTests,
QuickFunctonalTests, and FunctonalTests before checking in the code!

Of course, this may not work with every project, but so far it has for
me. No biggie though, so don't start throwing flames anyone. :)

> > On 2002-08-07 at 12:27 james.dobson@... wrote:
> > >Hi Everyone,
> > >
> > >Is it possible to automatically add all the tests of a test
> class to
> > a
> > >suite
> > >without using 'suite.addTestSuite(MyTest.class)'?
> > >
> > >I have a test class that can test a number of classes from the
> same
> > >hierarchy. Let's say for arguments sake that I have
> created two
> > child
> > >classes (ChildA and ChildB) of type JTextComponent and both of
> them
> > >override
> > >a number of methods such as setText. I have a number of tests
> that
> > test
> > >the
> > >newly overridden methods. I have created a constructor for the
> class
> > that
> > >looks something like this:
> > >
> > > public MyTest(String name, JTextComponent component)
> > > {
> > > super(name);
> > > this.component = component;
> > > }
> > >
> > >My problem is this: I want to run this test twice, once for
> childA
> > and
> > once
> > >for childB. But I don't want to type in the tests individually
> e.g.
> > >
> > > public class MyTestClient
> > > {
> > > public static Test suite()
> > > {
> > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > >
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> ChildA()));
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> ChildA()));
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> ChildA()));
> > > ........
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> ChildA()));
> > >
> > > // Then the same for childB
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> ChildB()));
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> ChildB()));
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> ChildB()));
> > > ........
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> ChildB()));
> > > return suite;
> > > }
> > > public static void main(String[] args)
> > > {
> > >
> > junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(MyTestClient.class);
> > > }
> > > }
> > >
> > >How I would like to write the suite method is something like
> this:
> > >
> > > public static Test suite()
> > > {
> > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > >
> > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here to
> indicate
> > I
> > >want to test ChildA */)
> > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here to
> indicate
> > I
> > >want to test ChildB */)
> > > }
> > >
> > >Hope this is a sensible question!
> > >
> > >James
